STBLKeyStringList.Text: (From Being Near Algae at Night)
(From Picking Grapes in the Wild)
(From Picking Tartosian Flowers)
(From Romance at the Lover's Tree)
(From Sea Swimming)
(From Tossing a Coin in the Fountain)
(From Romance in the Village Square)
(From Swimming Near the Waterfall)
(From Asking About Wedding Day)
(From Being Asked About Wedding Day)
{0.SimFirstName} found a message in a bottle buried in the sand!
(From Putting Down A Bouquet)
(From Doing a Group Wedding Dance Together)
Gossip fresh off the grapevine!
The City Hall offers quick weddings for those visiting who can't wait another day. Sometimes love just won't let you wait, eh?

They say Lady Matilda Tartosa used to live in a grand castle close to Hideaway Falls. Nobody can find the ruins, though. We do know that she used the Falls for illicit trades with pirates, but perhaps the castle ruins lie elsewhere.

Ages ago, a local shipwright carved the likeness of Princess Cordelia and her pirate lover, Rodrigo De Pablo, into the figurehead of a ship. When the ship sank those who remembered their love carried the figurehead to the top of the hill by Hideaway Falls as a reminder. A year passed and it magically began to sprout leaves and branches, a sign that their love lived on even though Rodrigo had passed. Today, you can visit the tree, and if your heart is pure, some of that love magic will rub off on you!
Don't forget to visit the local patisserie in Tartosa. We're famous for our fruit tarts and pastries, but it's also great if you want to sample some of the amazing wedding cakes they can whip up.
Aren't the hot air balloons in the sky romantic?

It's a common rumor around here that when the Thebe Estate was built, construction was funded using a chest of pirate's gold. There's another rumor that after he built the Villa, Rodrigo Thebe buried the rest of the gold somewhere near the village. If you could find it, you'd be rich! Then again, they sure seemed to spend an awful lot to make that place look luxe, didn't they? Maybe all that's left is a bit of pocket change.

Everyone knows about the glowing tides at night. It's said the strange glow used to draw in lost pirates, in fact. But the beaches have even more surprises in store, you know! If you search the shores, you'll sometimes find a message in a bottle. They wash up fairly regularly.

Sims around here are always talking about how Arnessa Thebe once sailed a little rowboat over Hideaway Falls? She broke a leg—literally. That's why they put in the bridge—to keep Sims from trying to sail over!
Did you know that the fruit we use in our world-famous tarts is local fruit? Yeah! You could even go out and pick your own if you wanted.
Have you noticed the flower cart in town? They get their flowers locally, for the most part. If you wanted, you could probably even go out and pick some of your own.

We see so many proposals here! It's the romantic aura of the land. Also, it's great for dates! Off the top of my head, you could take a dip at the base of Hideaway Falls, watch the glowing waves at night, take a walk on the beach, or visit Porto Luminoso's Village fountain. The Lover's Tree is also a popular destination, of course.
Did you know that if you visit the beach at night you might see the ocean glow? Some say that's what attracted Princess Cordelia to Tartosa back in the day.
The Porto Luminoso fountain is always a romantic spot to visit. I always see couples cuddled up on the edge.

Everyone loves the area's fruit tarts. I'm more of a macaron person myself. I suppose it seems a little, well, on the nose for someone like me but I don't actually like putting on airs, you know. Hand me a box of macarons from the patisserie here and as soon as I'm on my own, I'll devour it all in seconds. Don't tell anyone else that, though. I suppose I might want to preserve some element of aloofness here and there.
If you're here to find out where the pirate's gold is buried, I'll tell you what I tell everyone. I don't know. Please stop asking.

I hope you're having a lovely day, and perhaps a day with a little touch of romance. This is the perfect place to find love... or see it flourish. Of course, good relationships require careful cultivating!

I've gotten up to a bit of mischief in my day. I certainly won't own to any of it though! Though I will say, they did a spectacular job of repairing the fountain in the village square after, well, as I said: I won't own any of it. Mischief is best left to that Markovic man, don't you think?

Where's my favorite place in the area? Well, I've always felt drawn to the ocean. I love seeing the glowing tides at night. It makes me feel like I'm part of something truly mysterious and interesting. Isn't nature spectacular in that way?
I never say who my favorite grandchild is. Do I have one? Yes, of course. Nobody will ever find out who though! Not unless you want to bribe me with some macarons...

Oh, everyone says I'm related to Princess Cordelia. Who knows. That was such a long time ago. I'm not really one for nostalgia, you know. I live my life in the moment as much as I can. Don't you think that's the best way to go about things?

I don't really enjoy comedy. It was always a favorite of Hilary's though... For entertainment, I've always vastly preferred music. I've been playing the piano since I was three. I'm quite proficient. Lest you think I'm only interested in stuffier music, however; I'm actually quite interested in jazz improv!

To be honest, when I was younger, I always felt a little overwhelmed by all of the Princess Cordelia talk. That's a lot to live up to. I think I've forged my own path through life now though. I'm quite pleased to have lived the life I have. I just wish people didn't assume that I'm a snobby, unfriendly person. Nothing could be further from the truth! I just appreciate taking time to get to know a person before I open up too much. You have to keep yourself safe, you know.

What happened to Hector's father, you ask? Years ago, our stove malfunctioned and caught on fire. It certainly wasn't his cooking skill. He was an excellent chef. I remember how he used to make the best macarons. It was a tragic accident, but while I miss my husband I prefer to keep looking ahead. I can't wait to see what my grandchildren do with their lives.

People ask me all the time if I'm sad I'll be the last Thebe of the area. "It's such an old name..." they say. Perhaps, yes, and it's a bit sad. But I wanted my son to grow up without the same level of notoriety I experienced. There were times I felt like a curiosity rather than a person. Today, I'm glad Hector has his father's name. Its one of the ways I can remember him.

We're close enough, I'll admit it. Yes, my family does trace their lineage back to Princess Cordelia. City Hall has records from when my grandfather arrived, and we have historical artifacts all around the house. But speak with the town historian if you want to learn more, friend. Believe it or not, she's much more attuned to these matters and knows more about my family than I do!

I've been reading through old letters I received years ago. I rather miss my Aunt Queen and Uncle Eetion. My father and I used to visit them from time to time when I was a little girl. Those were my first trips on the ocean. To think that I have ancestors who spent time on pirate ships or submersibles! I thought I was quite the wild child just going out on a sailboat from time to time.

There's some evidence suggesting that Princess Cordelia and Lady Matilda Tartosa were very close during her stay here. It's unlikely they were lovers, given the Princess' feelings for Rodrigo. Still, the princess and Lady Tartosa spent a lot of time together at the beach, sailing the coast and devouring tarts. There's also evidence suggesting their relationship ended on rocky terms, but nobody knows for certain why. Some think Lady Tartosa had an affair with Rodrigo. Others believe she stiffed Princess Cordelia on a fruit tart, which was a serious offense back in those days. Frankly, it's a serious offense these days as well, given the quality of the tarts here.

A few years ago, famous artist, Igor Klobučar, was paid by Porto Luminoso to create an installation around the theme of romantic love. You'll find his finished piece, The Glass Heart, over in the gardens. The material represents the fragility of something as precious as love and the twists and turns we go through to find it. The two strands reminds us that its a journey you take with another person, too. They intertwine; crossing ways as Sims in love often do.

Tartosa is famous for its history with pirates. In the old days, they used to steal llamas and bring them here for a quick trade. Sometimes for gold, sometimes for tarts and pastries (and lots of them, I'd wager). Porto Luminoso is almost as famous for its tarts and pastries as it is for its history with pirates.

Lady Matilda Tartosa is perhaps the area's most famous noble. We don't have lords or ladies here anymore, of course. She was the youngest of three children and the last to inherit her title. Her eldest sister, Gianna, loved maps and left to chart the world, never returning. Her brother, Luca, was next in line and something of an astronomer. He would spend his nights looking up into the sky through a telescope he invented himself. It's said one night he simply disappeared. Nobody knows what happened to him. They both left Matilda here on her own, and she proved to be a very fruitful steward of the area. Most notably she increased trade and gave the area its first real staple: desserts.

There's a long list of pirates who visited here. Some of the most famous were Rodrigo De Pablo, of course, Two-Eye Charlie - later known as One-Eye Charlie - plus Captain Rachael the Fearsome, Raider Rad who, well, raided, Dash who was the shortest yet fastest pirate ever, Five Finger Fran, First Mate Barnacle Bob, and even the Dread Pirate Morgan on the Red Annie.

History will never know exactly why Princess Cordelia left Tartosa. We know she was one of the first Sims to explore the arctic waters in her submersible, the Eppsilon, and that was after she had already left. But why? Perhaps she, like the locals, was afraid it was only a matter of time before the dreaded sloths swam to our shores. Or perhaps she was an adventurer at heart, unable to settle in one spot for long. Maybe it was the death of her beloved Rodrigo that pushed her away? We'll never know for sure, but I certainly love thinking about it.

Rodrigo De Pablo was Princess Cordelia's third pirate boyfriend - yes, third! - and perhaps the greatest love of her life. It's said he was rather clumsy, and there's a lot of historical speculation around how he actually died. Some say his peg leg caught on fire aboard the Eppsilon, the Princess' ship. Others say he had an affair with Lady Tartosa and Princess Cordelia hired a witch to trap him inside a glass bottle she cast out to sea. I've also heard he choked on a tart, which seems the least ridiculous to me. Either way, history knows that when Princess Cordelia departed Tartosa, her beloved Rodrigo was not with her.

Lady Matilda Tartosa was the last of the nobles in Tartosa. She never married, nor had a lover—despite having a dazzling array of suitors. Nobody knows why. What we do know is that she lived out her days here, a diligent steward of her position and privilege, eventually dying of old age. In her last days, she saw the land given back to the people who have run it together ever since.

People are always asking me why its assumed that Arnessa Thebe is related to Princess Cordelia, since its well-known that Princess Cordelia left. Well, after a bit of digging, I discovered some evidence at City Hall stating that twenty years after she left, a gentleman by the name of Rodrigo Thebe returned. He claimed that his father had died here and his mother was the late Princess. With his vast fortune, Rodrigo had Thebe Estate built. Supposedly, there are some ancestors still around today.

Why is Tartosa famous for its pastries? Well, its where the tart was invented! Lady Matilda Tartosa loved fruit, you see, and one of her suitors created the dessert to impress her- going so far as to name it after her. Demand for the confectionary went up when the pirates started arriving to trade their stolen llamas. At that point, there was what is now known as 'The Great Tart Crisis." Due to a lack of supply, other pastries had to be made to satisfy the needs of supply and demand. Lucky for me, I can also grab a macaron anytime I like, too.

Back in the old days, pirates were always arriving at port to trade their stolen llamas for tarts and treats. There was one llama, however, that became something of a town legend. His name was Doug. They say he could spit over forty feet, which is utterly ridiculous. But that's not why he's famous, in fact. One day, a Pirate named Two-Eye Charlie arrived to steal back the llamas, and the villagers were too terrified to fight back. Doug wasn't afraid. He spat directly into Two-Eye Charlie's eye, renaming him One-Eye Charlie. He left in rather a hurry soon thereafter!

No, Princess Cordelia wasn't originally from here. Her kingdom was not too far away across the sea. When the Great Sloth Invasion took place, she escaped on her submersible, the Eppsilon, with her first pirate boyfriend Captain Long John Buttercups. They didn't come here though. She came here much later—and with a different pirate. That Cordelia certainly had a type, didn't she?

I asked about the Lover's Tree when I arrived here. Most believe that long ago, a local shipwright carved the likeness of Princess Cordelia and Rodrigo De Pablo into the figurehead of a ship. When the ship sank, those who remembered their love carried it to the top of the hill by Hideaway Falls as a reminder. A year passed, and it magically began to sprout leaves and branches: a sign that their love lived on even though Rodrigo had passed. But I think, as romantic as that is, sometimes a tree is just a tree. Dominique is utterly fascinated by it all the same, though.

The Tartosa area was originally settled by the Tartosa family. They had a castle along the cliffs, but the section it was on fell into the water, never to be seen again. I occasionally wonder if it would be worthwhile to dive and look for artifacts, but Dominique tells me that it'd be a fool's errand.

Was Thebe Estate built with pirate's gold? Most people seem to think so, but there's no substantial evidence in the City Hall records. It was quite an expensive investment, but who knows where the money came from.

The Tartosa locals at the time of the Great Sloth Invasion were terrified the sloths might make it here. After all, sloths are surprisingly strong swimmers. They use their long arms to propel through the water at an alarming speed they're never able to attain on land. Thankfully, they never reached our shores. We might not be here today if they had. I shudder to think!

Greta Laurent resembles the descriptions I've read about Princess Cordelia. Mostly her adventurous nature, but perhaps it's also her penchant for mischief. Arnessa has that as well. I think Greta is her favorite.
Something I've learned in life... choose to live somewhere you love. You'll find so much more enjoyment in the day-to-day.
My favorite piece of life advice: Always invest in those you care about. Relationships fade over time if they are not properly tended. They're like flowers in need of care.
Dominique and I were friends long before we fell in love. We almost didn't end up together. I'm thankful every day we did.
I love talking about the area's history. Most around here don't have the same thirst for knowledge I do, so I'm pleased that you are interested.
I absolutely adore Mateo's melodies. If you've never heard that man play on the piano, you really should hire him and have the opportunity. What a lovely and talented person.
No, I'm not originally from Tartosa. Camille and I met here, became friends here, and were eventually married here. We always knew that when we retired we would once again be... here.
Sure I know all of the best locations for picture-perfect paintings. But I'm not about to just share all of my secrets with anyone, am I. Great art must be experienced through adventure!

I've lived all over the world, actually. Windenburg was lovely, and probably my second favorite. Tartosa is where I'll live out the rest of my days, though. If you don't live in your favorite locale, are you even living?

I do love a good book, you know. A nice cozy mystery or, better still, a romantic story set against the backdrop of a historical moment. I've been trying to get Camille to write one about the area for years. A historical fiction, drama'd up to be fun.

Oh, I had the opportunity to meet Igor Klobučar when he was in Porto Luminoso installing his sculpture. Artist to artist! Can you imagine? What a charming Sim. Did you know he used to be a hatmaker for llamas? Hated it. You have to chase your dreams, even if it does lead you away from llamas from time to time.
What is my favorite book? Could I even pick one?! The Chronicles of Rodiek by Dominick VanDeesel is very good as is A Game of Groans by Greg Q.Q. Vartin. I could go on all day, really, but I won't.
Faiz is a poetic soul. I do hope he finds love soon. He's too sweet a rose to go unnoticed, don't you think?

I do love dancing. Any sort really, but slow dancing is by far my favorite. What's more romantic than twirling on a dance floor with the one you love, moving with grace and charm... it makes me want to get married all over again!

I don't think about the family feud between the Markovics and the Laurents much. It's such a lovely area. Why doesn't everyone try and get along for once? Let bygones be bygones. If I felt like holding a grudge, I still wouldn't be speaking with one of my dearest friends after she critiqued my last art installation!

About a decade ago, I spent a lot of time painting Thebe Estate. Camille was fascinated by its history and it inspired something in me as well. Arnessa was always kind enough to bring tea out to me as I worked. A spot of black tea really gets the mind percolating.

You want to find some of the most beautiful, underappreciated views in Porto Luminoso? Follow the trails behind the buildings. Mazes, beaches, overlooks - all of it gorgeous. Wait for the sunlight to hit them just right, and you have a special setting for your art.

Maybe it's obvious, but Hideaway Falls is one of the most beautiful spots in Tartosa. When Camille and I met, we spent most of our time there. That was my favorite painting subject at the time. Well, after her, of course.

I can't tell you how many times I've painted the Lover's Tree. From every angle, mind you! As intimate as I am with it as a subject, I can't help but feel it does have a connection with the Sims who come to visit—even if the rumors aren't true.

Have you noticed the hill on the side of Porto Luminoso? You can get the most beautiful top down views of the village from there. A new perspective does wonders to shake things up if you're feeling a bit stuck.
If you want to paint something colorful, try the marina. The boats are splendidly vibrant and who doesn't love a good seagull?

Down the coast in Terra Amorosa, there is this darling grove of trees. A lot of Sims who come here to get married take pictures there, but it's beautiful for paintings as well. Just imagine what some of those old trees have witnessed in days gone by. If I stand still enough, I sometimes swear I can hear the trees communicating. But that's silly, isn't it? I know, I sound like an overly whimsical artist, don't I?

Sometimes I paint Sims and not scenes. After Camille, Faiz is my favorite. He has such a light in his eyes. It's the exuberance of youth, I imagine, though there's something unique about Faiz that I truly admire.
My favorite spot to paint? Right here in Porto Luminoso. The people, the sea, the painted buildings. Nature is lovely, but this is life as it's meant to be experienced: right in the thick of things!

Everyone loves the fruit tarts around here, and I do too! But I also love the macarons. And the cake. Okay, maybe I just have a sweet tooth. But if you live here, it's practically a requirement. You try running a flower cart with the smell of amazing things baking nearby all the time without developing one!

Hey there! I hope you're having a lovely day. If you didn't know, I run the flower cart in the village. Feel free to come by anytime to pick out the best flowers the area has to offer, or just to say hello. I always love chatting with people.

Once I picked up the book, "Pickup Lines for the Flirtatiously Inept" by Dr. Phyllis. I'm not sure it was very helpful; I much preferred "Diplomacy for Dummies" by Dimitry Hard. Of course, Dimitry tends to skimp a bit on the romance, but nobody's perfect.

Yes, I sell flowers from my cart. But as a tip, if you need to save some money.... you can always find wild flowers growing outside the village around here. They're lovely, too, and hand-picked flowers always send a special message when you give them to others.

Most people don't know it, but I also really enjoy photography. There are some great places around here to take pictures. If you're close with Dominique, she might give you some pointers. As a painter she's already found all the best spots. Once I found her hanging upside down from the Lover's Tree to "get a new perspective" on life. Artists, eh?

Do you have a favorite poet? Mine is Mabel Eloise Clift. She works with post-modern verse, and her poems are surprisingly short. Very impactful though. I like the one called Rose. I can recite it from heart. It goes like this: "Red. A rose."
Did you know I love writing poetry? Of course I do. Flowers. Romance. It speaks to my soul! I could tell you chapter and verse just about how much I love to write, well, chapter and verse!
I spend a lot of my day daydreaming—when I'm not speaking to a customer, of course. There's so much I want out of life, especially love.

I really appreciate it when people take time out of their day to talk with me. Even though things seem a little more laid-back on Tartosa, sometimes people get so absorbed in the day-to-day that they don't stop to, well, smell the roses. Sorry, that's so corny! But I'm happy to talk with you more!

How are you enjoying things in Tartosa? You know my family lives in the Laurent Villa. Many still call it the Thebe Estate. My family decided to change things up a bit. Maybe pull a little attention away from some of the family history, y'know? Anyway, I live there and we also own a couple other spots around here. Hopefully, you'll get to see them all.

Sure, you can get married at City Hall if you're in a big rush, but why not opt for a big ceremony and reception? My family's great at helping everyone set up the best wedding you can buy, even on a smaller budget. Ask anyone! Well, don't ask Mateo Markovic. The guy's nice enough, but, well, local rivalries die hard I guess.

My kids, Greta and Jace, can be a bit of a handful sometimes. But I bet if you asked my wife, she'd say I'm just as much of a handful. What can I say? I can be a bit of a party creature from time to time. But that Greta, wow, can she get into some serious mischief when your back is turned.

Have you tried the roast duck down in the village where the restaurants are? You absolutely have to! That's one of my wife's family recipes, you know. Well, a lot of the recipes in those shops are. Her parents started those restaurants and kind of had a restaurant empire of sorts here on Tartosa. If you don't like to eat meat, there are some pretty fantastic veggie dumplings, too.

Everyone always talks up Hideaway Falls and don't get me wrong, they're beautiful, but I love just standing out near the beach and looking towards the sea. There's a whole world of possibility out there, you know? Sometimes I wonder if I'd like to travel the world a bit, but then I remember that I have everything I need right here at home.

We don't talk about a lot of the local legends within my own family. I heard a lot of stories about Princess Cordelia and pirate lore just from being in school. When I was little, I searched the house up and down for secret doors. I was convinced that there was a hidden room filled with pirate treasures. You know what I found? One antique button, a hair bow, and a whole lot of dust bunnies.

My marriage to Hilary is pretty amazing now, but for a while I wasn't so sure we'd get that storybook ending. I admit it: I've been kind of an insensitive guy in the past. I broke someone's heart a while back, and it's been hard to forgive myself. But Hilary sees through a lot of my faults and we work together to be better people.

I've thought about taking my mother's last name. There's a lot of expectation that comes with it though. Some locals seem annoyed I wouldn't want it, but it's my life. That's just the way I was raised. I'm privileged, no doubt about it, but I work hard too and want all that work to be seen as something of my own doing.

Did you know there is a playground just outside of town? It's the perfect place to take the kids. Pirate themed, of course, given our history. My husband comes from a family with swashbucklers, you know?

I love cooking. It's just so much fun and there are always interesting new recipes to try, or ways to experiment to make your own. I have a lot that were handed down to me by my parents, but I'm always working to create my own new recipes.

I wasn't born here. My parents were chefs in a big city and wanted to raise me in an environment that's a little bit quieter. I guess they visited Tartosa for a day when they were traveling on their honeymoon, and it made a lasting impression. So much so that they moved out here just to start up a restaurant, then two, and then start catering for weddings.

When Jace and Greta were toddlers, I used to take them to the waterfall. The lagoon has a shallow area that was perfect for them to splash in. They were so cute! I know it sounds trite, but the saying's true: they really do grow up too fast.

Have you met the Markovics yet? They're really sweet. Lucia is my best friend; I can tell her anything. Mateo can be a little standoffish with my family because I think he thinks of us as rivals, but I think of our families as complementing one another. We all work together to make this place better for everyone.

I've always wondered what Tartosa was like before it became a stopping place for pirates. It's hard to find a lot of traces of people before then, so maybe no one was living here. It seems hard to believe now, given how many people travel through here each year.

Even though cooking has been a family affair for me, I'm hoping my kids choose a career path that they like. I secretly hope they do something completely different, even. Greta is so interested in the flowers around here; maybe botany is for her? Jace is more of a wild child, though he's very social and chatty.

When I first met Arnessa, I was absolutely terrified. I mean, you know the rumors are true, right? She's related to Princess Cordelia. As soon as I heard that she was basically royalty, I was on notice. I expected her to be a bit of a snob, but she's not at all. Whether she admits to it or not, she has a real penchant for mischief. She loves playing little pranks on people. I'm wondering if that's rubbed off a little too much on the kids...

When I was younger, I loved going up to the Lover's Tree and sitting there for hours with a good book. It just has a nice aura about it. There are a lot of legends about where it came from; something about a figurehead? I've also heard something about how it grew in a way that looked similar to doomed lovers who traveled here once. While I love a good story, personally, I think it's just a very old - and very nice - tree.
I've been playing guitar as long as I can remember. Sometimes I don't even really think in words or images, I just think in music. If you're passionate about music, I'm sure you understand.

At first glance, it seems like Tartosa is all about the wedding industry. If you ask Mateo, he'd say the same - he's pretty absorbed in it. But it's also a beautiful place with a really unique history!
Have you met my daughter, Tomi, yet? She has the most interesting mind! She's going to amaze everyone someday with an amazing piece of art or music - just you wait.

The cuisine here is so interesting! My best friend, Hilary, is this amazing chef. Her family was in the restaurant business. She keeps an eye on the market stalls she opened up in Porto Luminoso. You absolutely have to try the mutton biryani. If you don't eat meat, I totally understand, but if you do: it's practically a transcendent experience the first time you sample it!

There's definitely a bit of tension and, well, drama around here. I don't like getting into it too much because gossiping really isn't my thing. But I suppose it's like any other place; you know who you friends are, and you know who you might want to keep an eye on!

It's really funny, you know. Mateo and I have wanted to get married for ages - before our daughter was born, in fact, but the stars never really aligned. We became a musical duo, then started playing for everyone else's wedding. One day we woke and realized... we never even had our own. Don't worry, though, we'll be changing that soon.

You know I really don't like gossip, but since he's kind of inescapable given that he's, well, the big wheel of the wedding industry: Hector can be a little tricky. He and I dated once and he was a pretty big jerk. But he's married to my best friend, so I do my best to keep my mouth shut and keep the peace.

When Mateo and I met, he was so sweet. I'd been going through a real rough patch and he was playing piano at the lounge for tips. He locked eyes with me and immediately began playing this beautiful composition - almost moved me to tears! Now, we make music together.

I bet you've heard all about the Thebe Estate and pirate gold and all that. One thing I wanted to mention, though, is that Arnessa Thebe may seem like a really difficult-to-approach woman, she's actually a real doll once you talk to her. She just doesn't like being made to feel like she's being mined for details about her unique family.
Both Lucia and I can sing. She plays the guitar though and I the piano. Our skillsets complement each other well.
I've been playing piano since I was five. My grandmother used to have me play for her when I'd visit, so I started taking classes. It was never easy to impress her! But I always managed.

Sure, the Laurents have been here longer... well the Thebes have been here longer; the distinction matters a bit. But the Markovics are just as passionate about the wedding industry! What do you remember more about a wedding: the amazing music or the venue? To me, music is always what makes the biggest impression.

Hector Laurent is trying to hog all of the good wedding business around these parts. The Laurents have a stranglehold on the wedding industry, and they don't make room for others. Lucia and I have had to work very hard to keep our business booming.

Tartosa really is the perfect place to get married. That's why business is so good here in the wedding industry. I mean, between the Falls and the ocean views you're hardly hurting for a great locale, and everything about the ambiance here spells love.

You know, sometimes I wonder if I would trade a pastry for a llama. The answer is, yes. I would totally do that. I actually would really like a llama. Do you think Lucia would agree to getting one? She seems Llama-friendly, right?
I've been called a goofball before, but I ask you... would a goofball ever pursue a minor in puppeteering? Granted, I never graduated.. but I think my endeavor speaks for itself!

Am I more of a business man or a family man? You know, if I had to pick, I'd choose family every time. Even when we've had some tough times, Lucia and Tomi and I have always had each other to rely on. Can't beat that, can you?

When Lucia and I moved here we lived in Porto Luminoso, but it was a little too close to the Laurents for my liking, so we moved to Terra Amorosa to get a little space and quiet. And wouldn't you know it, that move turned out for the best. The muses speak to me a little more out there. Or is that me just talking to myself?

Between you and me, I was sad Tomi was more interested in painting than music... at first. I've really grown to appreciate her preferences the past few years. She's going to be an amazing artist! Or whatever she decides she wants to be!

I'm devoted to my daughter, Tomi. I've never known a prouder father. I'm sure she'll be an extraordinary painter someday. She's already very advanced! The stuff other parents might just put on a fridge is stuff that, from Tomi, really belongs in a museum. She's dabbling in this new style called post abstract impressionist style. I have no idea what those words mean, but I know it means my daughter is pretty incredible.

Elegant and simple, perfect to decorate for the wedding of your dreams and keep curious uninvited guests at bay with these beautifully crafted curtains. Sewn from cloth from the best seamsters of Tartosa, this curtain will make your wedding party look clean and somewhat vintage chic.

Like its original version, this curtain is exquisitely crafted by Tartosa seamsters putting a touch of Tartosa in your wedding to remember.
Slightly Longer - Still Effortless Cinched Curtain

If a cinched look is not in your taste or needs for your venue décor, this version of the Effortless Curtain line is the right choice. Some may think it is just cut cloth but don't let its effortless look deceive you, Tartosa seamsters carefully cut and pleated these fabrics with love and care so your venue looks perfect so all the newlyweds shine!
Effortless Straight Curtain
A bit of more fabric makes everything seem more magical! Perfect for weddings, and who knows maybe you can use them to twirl in the dancefloor if you don't have a partner to dance with.
Slightly Longer - Still Effortless Straight Curtain

In modern times, the dragon represents the wealth and strength for the groom while the phoenix represents the bride, signifying grace and renewal of life. The Light of the Dragon

To the Moon and Back - Orb Lamp

Give tribute to your favorite couple's happiness, or why not - your own! This centerpiece is perfectly aligned with candles and a beautiful flower motif to inspire romance to any occasion and location.

Create a romantic atmosphere with this exquisite composition of nature and fire. Admire the balance of simple natural elements: the leaves, the bark, the majestic anthurium with its lovely heart-shaped leaf. It’s also toxic, but that’s another story and you shouldn’t eat it, anyhow.
Candlelight Composition

Lone Candle in the Hall

Marigolds are popular in Hindu weddings as they represent the sun, meaning brightness and positive energy. Don’t you hate it when you’re at a wedding and you can’t get your drink on ‘cause it looks like it’s the Libation Engineer’s first day? Hoops, There It Is

Modeled in strong and weather resistant materials, these chairs are a modern vision of chairs used by Tartosa royalty. Comes in a variety of colors to make your gatherings and weddings stand out in the right places. This chair is discreet yet sophisticated and won't ghost you in performance.

A weaved chair generally has a casual but cool appeal, and the Weaved with Love is no different. The weave pattern supports your back comfortably as well as its gorgeous and simple seat. Made to bask in the sun in the gorgeous summers of Tartosa, this lounge chair is made to impress. With simplicity and elegance, lounge like those famous Sims when they are photographed while they are on holiday. Feel the breeze, the sun, and feel expensive while doing so.

Sit your newlyweds in this plush and regal looking loveseat. Made from exquisite fabrics and frames - including a garland of beautiful marigold - your newlyweds, and anyone really, will feel like sitting in the happiest and most comfortable of clouds on their special day.

Well, now your dreams have all come to fruition. You’re the proud owner of the Gravy Fountain Mark IV. The Gravy Fountain Mark IV Platform

Visit Tartosa's Villa Vigna and enjoy Porto Luminoso's breathtaking cliffside views. Stay in and enjoy all the amenities this rental has to offer or take a walk down through the vineyards and visit the village for a small shopping trip. Just don't forget to try the local cuisine!
Villa Vigna

Thebe Estate is one of Porto Luminoso's historical buildings—its origins are draped in rumor and are often gossiped about by curious locals. The Thebe family, now the Laurents, have lived here for generations as noted by their fine collection of family heirlooms.

"Laurent" may be a newer name in the area, but the family certainly isn't. For generations, they've owned the local wedding venue, the cornerstone of the wedding industry in the area. And Hilary's family opened the first food stall in the village square back when they moved to the area. Now she's a chef in her parent's restaurant, and the local food market has flourished. Together, this family forms a wedding-industry powerhouse.
Laurent
Thebe Estate

The La Coppia Serena may be the local go-to for wedding ceremonies, but every Sim knows Celebrazioni d'Amore is the best place to host a true party. Afterwards, head into the gardens for a stroll or back behind the lounge for a romantic view of the sea.
Celebrazioni d'Amore

Tucked snugly along Tartosa's sunset coastline, Baia dell'amore offers the best of the area: soft and sandy beaches to share with a lover, plus nighttime bioluminescent shores that are perfect for lighting up a romantic dip... and only a short stroll from Porto Luminoso.
Baia dell'amore

Situated just off the Terra Amorosa estuary, close to Hideaway Falls, and overlooked by the Lover's Tree, Via Romanza is a prime piece of real estate. Its location in the heart of Tartosa's love industry begs the question: what will this plot of land become? The wedding industry's next big venue? A rental for the many coupled lovebirds who return on honeymoon? Or simply a home for those who find themselves moved by the land's romantic ambiance?
Via Romanza

This adorable home hides off Porto Luminoso's shore on tiny Piccola Luce island. Its decor pulls from nature around it—the sea's cerulean waters and the coast's famous, apricot sunsets. There's no better home for a Sim seeking solitude in a love-laced land.
Piccola Luce

The golden crown of Tartosa's wedding industry. Sims travel from all around the world to partake of the area's many romance-oriented accommodations, and it all comes together here on the day of each Sim's wedding. Indoor or outdoor, this venue has hosted a multitude of dream weddings and will continue to do so for generations to come.
La Coppia Serena

The woods surrounding this home create a natural barrier of privacy and peace, the perfect place for a Sim seeking to benefit from the area's attractions yet retain sweet solitude. Years back, this building was the local nectary, but the establishment has since been refurbished into a home for the Markovic family.

The Markovic family are locally-renowned for their contribution to the musical-side of the wedding industry, despite having put off their own wedding time and time again. This is in no small part due to relations between them and the Laurent family being rather strained. Mateo believes the Laurents have a stranglehold on local wedding business and works hard to retain relevance. While Lucia's animosity is directed at Hector, a former lover, all the drama and work has kept them busy and unwed!
Markovic
The Old Wood Nectary

At first glance, it's obvious this starter is a steal. Scenic views overlook Hideaway falls, the entirety of the Terra Amorosa estuary area, and the Lover's Tree. However, it's the hidden history that makes this spot so particularly notable to the locals. Shhh. It's a secret, though! A bit of sleuthing and you're bound to discover what makes this lot one of the best that Tartosa has to offer.
Rifugio dei Pirati

Faiz is a poetic, hopeless romantic living in an area that specializes in the wedding industry—a constant reminder of his single status. He spends his days in the village square, selling flowers, and daydreaming of his missing soulmate. Perhaps one day, his dreams will come true. But until then... he has a flower for everyone.
Jaleel

Years ago, Dominique and Camille were married in Tartosa. Each year they returned on vacation in hopes of re-experiencing the love - and rich local culture - only Tartosa offers. Once both women retired, they decided to make their yearly trip more permanent. \n\nDominique is an artist who now spends her days painting landscapes and portraits in the village square and Camille is a writer who has taken an interest in the area's storied history. Many consider her to be the Porto Luminoso historian and she can often be found enjoying the outdoors alongside Dominique while chatting about local history with anyone willing to listen.
Sotos

"Stubbed my foot yesterday on an anchor, so I'm spending the day beachside. I thought it might be interesting to write my first message in a bottle. Today's thoughts: Sims are always asking me what happened to my ship, Peggy Leg. Well, she sank. Technically... I sank her, but I prefer to avoid technicalities of such a nature. It was an incident involving some kelp, a Mersim, and a dolphin. Anyways, I hope if anyone finds this letter they're in healthier condition than me. Stay safe out there. It's a dangerous world. - Captain Rodrigo De Pablo." \n\nThe corner of the letter is stained in ink, as if an inkwell was clumsily tipped and spilled over the paper.

"Hello! My name is Jace. Tomi told me that she threw a message in a bottle into the sea a few days ago, so I decided to try it too! I am 6 years old, and my favorite color is blue. I like listening to cool kids music and talking with my friends, especially Tomi. In my free time, I've been trying to find buried treasure like a pirate. My favorite place to play is on the pirate playground. Do you have a favorite color? I hope you have a nice day! - Jace"

"Hi! My name is Elsa Bjergsen, and I'm five and a half years old. I read that a message in a bottle once traveled for seventeen months over 14,500 kilometers from where it was cast into the sea. Isn't that neat? I hope mine goes even farther, and also that whoever finds it is having a very nice day. Please write me back. I live on the Crumbling Isle in Windenburg. P.S. My sister says this won't work, but I bet her five simoleons it would!"
"I be sending off a short riddle, matey. Solve it if ye can! Why are pirates pirates?" Written on the other side in large letters is the answer: "They just Arrrrr!"
"I'm sorry Temperance, but your calcium-rich sister has stolen my heart. Maybe in another life things could have worked out between us. - G."
"Hand in hand, we, Camille and Dominique, have pledged ourselves to each other. We send this message off on the day of our wedding. Two souls united in friendship and in love."

"The endless waves crash to and fro,
who this reaches I may never know.
Do your eyes sparkle as you read this?
The thought of my rose smiling makes me feverish.
I hope you feel the same as I,
 that our hopeful love may never die.
 And if you should ever find your way here,
you have a heart, a home, and endless cheer."

The message is signed with "FJ" encased in a small heart.

"I'm neither a pirate, nor the adventure she craves, but rather a dear friend. And so I'll send her off with everything but my unrequited love. A secret I share with the sea and no other, for they are alike. While I resemble the tides as they test the boundaries of these shores, returning each night in brilliance. She is as relentlessly free as the sea, untamed and trackless, a force to behold. I would not tame her even if I could." \n\nThe letter is signed with an elegant flourish, "Lady Matilda Tartosa"

"It's taken me a long time to get over Hector, and maybe I haven't truly forgiven him. Our relationship was doomed from the start. But I do really care for Hilary, and I'm glad she seems so happy. I'll always think she deserves better than him though. - Lu"

"Was it my desire for pirate gold or for the sweet, silly faces of the llamas? Surely no Sim would fault me for the latter. I've hid my dealings well, so perhaps history will never know how influential I was in Tartosa's privateer trade—that I invited them here. It wouldn't be proper of a lady, but then again... I've always been a bit of a rebel. Either way, my land thrives." \n\nThe letter is signed with an elegant flourish, "Matilda"

"I took the train to visit the sea today. My husband doesn't know. Ever since we moved to Senbamachi, I can tell something is... off. The leaves are beautiful and it's much quieter. I think the fresh air is good for the children, but is it good for my husband and me? - J"

"I'm not leaving due to sorrow. Rather, John's sudden death has reminded me how precious life is. A life of adventure would be most fulfilling, and I intend to make the most of every day. Perhaps I will return to the arctic waters and see the lights in the sky once again."
"Ye be readin' the letter I wrote, arrrr ye? Well, now you're cursed! Ha. Me and me trusty parrot will be free! - Captain Y. Eet"
"I meet everyone eventually. Even you. - Grim"
"You're Next!" The message is followed by an oddly off-kilter smiley face and a date from about seventy years prior.
"If you don't leave this bottle where you found it, the next time you're in a room alone, the door will disappear!"

"When I was young, I lived in the shadow of a legend, but I decided to tell my own story. I've explored the world—from historic Al Simhara to tiny Oasis Springs. I sailed over a waterfall, kissed a llama, climbed Mt. Komorebi, been madly in love, and raised my greatest pride.... my son. My life is full of memories, and in it's twilight, I send a wish into the ocean: Do not fear the shadows surrounding you, but rather step out and shine brightly."

"I spent the morning watching Dominique paint the harbor. When I grow up, I'd like to be just like her. She's so creative and interesting, and it's so sweet how in love she looks when Camille talks to her. I want a life like that. She told me she liked one of my paintings once, so maybe I'm on my way! - Tomi"
"I often gaze up at the moon and wonder if there is more to life. I just want to change myself, for better or worse."
"We send this wish adrift while on honeymoon at Sunlit Tides. May our marriage be as blissful as life is now." Encapsulated in a heart at the bottom are the names Daniel and Mary-Sue Pleasant.

Romantic sites and scenery have long graced the seaside region of Tartosa, creating the perfect setting for love and matrimonial pursuits. It isn't uncommon for vacationers and honeymooners alike to return year after year, seeking to re-experience the intimacy of visits past. They say there's a love story in the making for everyone. Just ask Tartosa's residents, and they'll excitedly gossip about local Wedding Industry shenanigans or the area's love-laced, historical past. But even if a Sim doesn't find their soulmate here, one thing is for certain... they're fated to fall in love with the land.
Tartosa

Want your Lot to reminisce about your destination beach holiday? Look no further! The "I Love Sand" terrain option will help you relive your wonderful memories of a fantastic voyage.
I Love Sand

Sims can now be engaged in Create-A-Sim so that you can start your wedding story right away. Once both Sims are created you will be able to select Fiancé from the Create-A-Sim relationship options for any Sims Young Adult and older.

You can also get married at a City Hall! Use your phone to travel with your Fiancé Sim to the Tartosa World map. Then select any lot in the Porto Luminoso neighborhood. City Hall is located around the back of the village square along the gardens. Click on the building to Get Married.

To elope immediately, click on your Fiancé Sim and choose the "Elope Immediately with..." interaction. This interaction has a double-linked ring icon and can be found towards the front of the interaction menu.

Both the "Elope Immediately" Sim interaction and the "Get Married" interaction on a wedding arch will allow Sims to tie-the-knot on-the-spot. You can also plan a wedding event if you want to customize your wedding experience, invite Sims, assign wedding roles, choose a location and time, or better control the flow of the wedding events. To do this, see the Tutorial section on "Wedding Event Planner." During the Wedding Ceremony Event, you can "Exchange Vows" to get married.

Once engaged, your Sims are ready to get married. Sims can 'tie the knot' a number of ways!
• Elope Immediately with a social interaction 
• Using a Wedding Arch
• At Tartosa's Porto Luminoso City Hall
• During a Wedding Ceremony or on-the-spot

To get married using a wedding arch, go into Build Mode and search "Wedding Arch." Place down a wedding arch and return to Live Mode. Click on and interact with the wedding arch to either Plan Wedding Event or Get Married.
Of course, you can still do this in Live Mode through Romantic interactions with another Sim!
Getting Married

There are two Aisle types that are available in three sizes. The first has flower petals to line the pathway and the other will appear mostly invisible once you leave Build Mode. The invisible version will highlight when you hover over it and then you will be able to select it to run interactions to send Sims down the aisle.
All aisles have a heart icon on one side to tell you which direction the Sims will walk towards when they walk down the aisle. The heart is where Sims will end up.

Wedding Aisles allow Sims to walk down the Aisle as Flower Pals, Ring Bearers, individually or as a pair. These objects can be placed down from Build mode almost anywhere that sims can walk however the terrain underneath them will need to be flat.
Wedding Aisles

After a Wedding Ceremony has been scheduled, you will be able to save a wedding cake for the event by selecting "Select as Cake for Wedding Ceremony" from the cake you want to save. Then the cake will be set aside until the wedding starts. Once the wedding event has started you will be able to "Place Cake" to put the cake out for the event.

Cakes can be placed almost anywhere, but to place a topper or to Cut the Cake Together the cake will have to be on a dining table. For most tables, the cake will need to be in the center, but for a larger round table it will need to be a little closer to the edge for Sims to reach it.

For many, Wedding Cakes are one of the most important things at a wedding. In Tartosa's Porto Luminoso, Sims are able to taste a variety of cake flavors at the patisserie stand near the village square. After the all important tasting, Sims will be able to purchase Wedding cakes through a computer, or make one themselves if they have the gourmet cooking skill.
Wedding Cake

Once your Sims are engaged, there are a few ways to plan a wedding or wedding event. Wedding events can be planned via the Computer, Phone, or Calendar. Events planned on the Computer and Phone will happen on the current day, while scheduling an event through the Calendar will let you schedule one on the day that you select. You will also have the ability to go back and edit events after they have been scheduled, the only requirements will be that you have selected the required Sims and a time and place for the event.

All Wedding Events have the ability to select Activities that help customize the event to fit your Sims. Each Wedding Event has a specific selection of Activities that are appropriate for that type of event. There is no limit to the number of activities that you select. While Activities will be listed to remind you during the event, there is no downside if you decide to not run these activities while the event is active.

In the Style Tab of the Wedding Ceremony event you will be able to enter Create-A-Sim to change the formal outfits of your Sims. Only the primary formal outfit will be selected for Wedding Ceremony event, but once the event has started you can change to any outfit you choose. You will also be able to request that Sims show up in a specific color, or clothing style under the Guest Attire section. There is also a spot to view your cake once you have selected one for your wedding.

Wedding Ceremony events have a few extra special selections available that can make your Sim's special day more unique. Your Sims can ask their friends and family to be part of their wedding as a Sim of Honor, an Officiant, a Ring Bearer, or a Flower Pal. Once Sims have been asked to be one of these special roles, you will be able to select them for this role in the Wedding Ceremony planner.
Planning Wedding Events

To gather Sims for a bouquet toss, click on the bouquet and Hold Bouquet. Then select Start Bouquet Throw on the bouquet or the terrain. Once Sims are gathered select a Sim to Toss the Bouquet to. Sims may need some open space to be able to toss the bouquet.

Wedding Bouquets can be purchased from the Flower Cart in Tartosa's Porto Luminoso village square. Sims will receive these flowers in their inventory and can hold onto them until the wedding. These flowers can be placed in the world as a decorative object or can be held by the Sim for a bouquet toss.
Wedding Bouquet
My Wedding Stories
Sun Faded Paint

Historians say Porto Luminoso's name originated when pirates arrived at shore, attracted by the glowing tides, the promise of trade, and the invention of the fruit tart. Overtime, the village flourished, and while still famous for its fruit tarts, Porto Luminoso's real claim to fame is its self-proclaimed-title as the wedding industry's premiere destination for romance and matrimonial services.
Porto Luminoso

A short trip up the coastline from Porto Luminoso is the loving land, known as Terra Amorosa to the locals. Whether fishing off the boardwalk, swimming at the bottom of secluded Hideaway Falls, or hiking up the hillside to visit the area's famous Lover's Tree, any Sim is bound to fall madly in love with the various charming sights and historic landmarks this lover's paradise has to offer.
Terra Amorosa
